Borrower Socialist Republic of Viet Nam
Project Description The  Project  will  improve  provincial  roads  in  18  provinces  in
northern Viet Nam to allow better access for the rural poor and to
connect districts and communes to the provincial cities and the
national highway network, contributing to poverty reduction, and
development of an effective national road network, and continued
reforms in the road sector.
Classification Poverty intervention
Thematic: Economic growth
Environmental Category B. The road improvements follow existing alignments.
Assessment Initial  environmental  examinations  of  nine  selected  core  roads
show that the environmental impact is expected to be minimal.
Rationale Efficient  road  transport  and,  in  particular  improved  access  is
essential for poverty reduction and economic development in Viet
Nam. Past efforts in the road subsector have mainly been directed
toward  upgrading  the  national  highway  system,  while  also
improving  basic  access  to  the  rural  population  by  improving
district and commune roads. One missing  part  in  the  network
development strategy has been improvement of provincial roads,
which  provide  access  to  the  provincial  capitals,  the  national
highway network, and the rural population through the district and
commune  roads.  Improving  the  provincial  roads  will  ensure
effective  transport  and  communication  between  the  rural
population  connected  by  commune  and  provincial  roads  with
market and distribution centers and the national highway network.
Another priority is continued reform and institutional strengthening
of the Viet Nam Road Administration (VRA) to become a modern
and efficient road management agency. The adopted sector loan
modality will support sustainable development of provincial roads
and allow flexibility in selecting prescreened subprojects forming
part of the provincial road sector development plan.
Objectives and Scope The  Project  will  contribute  to  poverty  reduction  and  economic
growth by improving transport efficiency. The objectives of the
Project are to (i) improve the provincial road network on both
social and economic grounds, (ii) provide improved access for
poor and disadvantaged groups living in rural communities, (iii)
strengthen  asset  management  capacity  and  maintenance
programs  of  VRA  and  the  provincial  departments  of  transport
(PDOTs),  (iv)  continue  institutional  strengthening  of  VRA  and
improve governance in the road subsector, (v) strengthen PDOT
capacity  to  prepare,  implement,  and  monitor  resettlement  and
ethnic minority development plans, and (vi) promote private sector
participation  in  the  delivery  of  road  infrastructure  and
maintenance.

I.  THE PROPOSAL
1. I submit for your approval the following Report and Recommendation on a proposed
loan to the Socialist Republic of Viet Nam for the Provincial Roads Improvement Sector Project.
II.  INTRODUCTION
2. Viet Nam has a relatively extensive road network, but the quality of its roads is generally
poor. Recognizing this impediment to economic development and poverty reduction, the Asian
Development Bank (ADB), along with the Japan Bank for International Cooperation (JBIC), and
the World Bank (WB), became involved in the road subsector in the early 1990s. Priority was
given to improving national highway 1, which over its 2,200 kilometers (km) length connects the
border of the People’s Republic of China in the north to the southernmost tip of the country. In
three subsequent loans,1 ADB financed improvements of various sections of the highway.
Realizing the need to improve access for the rural population, components for improvement of
provincial district and commune roads were also included in two of these loans. Emphasis was
also given to institutional development with technical assistance (TA) to start the process of
developing  the  newly  created  (1998)  Viet  Nam  Road  Administration  (VRA)  into  a  modern
institution and to develop the policy base for sustainable development of roads in Viet Nam.
ADB also helped finance improvements to two high priority Greater Mekong Subregion (GMS)
road improvement projects.2
3. Now that the improvements of national highway 1 are either completed or under way,
attention has shifted to other road priorities, specifically provincial, district, and commune roads.
While ADB, the Department for International Development (DFID) of the United Kingdom, JBIC,
Japan International Cooperation Agency (JICA), and WB have shown considerable interest in
improving district and commune roads, little attention was paid to improving the connecting
provincial  roads.  To  address  this  missing  part  of  the  network  development  strategy,  the
Government of Viet Nam asked ADB to provide project preparatory TA3 covering preliminary
design; economic analysis; and environmental, social, poverty, and other studies needed to
prepare the proposed Project for provincial roads in the northern part of the country, targeting
three of Viet Nam’s poorest regions. Under that TA, a provincial road subsector development
plan (PRSDP) was prepared. The Government also has a transport investment program, which
meets  the  priority  needs  of  the  national  economy.  While  the  Government  has  shown
competence in implementing previous projects, a sector loan is considered appropriate. The
Fact-Finding Mission visited Viet Nam from 14 May to 1 June 20014 and subsequent missions
were  fielded  in  July  and  August  2001  to  conduct  further  policy  dialogue  on  institutional
development. The Appraisal Mission was fielded from 9 to 18 October 2001. This report is
based  on  the  missions’  findings;  discussions  with  Government  officials  and  staff  from

III.  BACKGROUND
A.  The Transport Sector
1.  General
4. Viet Nam is a poor country. Of the total population of 73 million, some 37 percent live
below the poverty line (1998).5 Although poverty has declined during the last decade, the rate of
decline and the incidence vary greatly in the country. Three regions account for the largest
proportion of poor; two are located in the northern part of the country. Urbanization is starting to
grow rapidly, but about 80 percent of the population still live in rural areas. Poverty is largely a
rural phenomenon with 90 percent of the poor living in rural areas and 34 percent of the rural
population living below the poverty line. However, the urban poor are also vulnerable, suffering
from unemployment, limited access to health and education, and poor living conditions. This
problem is being tackled through various assistance and Government projects. Large disparities
exist between ethnic minority groups and kinh, the national ethnic majority. In 1998, 31 percent
of kinh were living below the poverty line, compared with 75 percent of the other 53 ethnic
minorities. In addition, the actual gains in poverty reduction are fragile as many households are
classified as just slightly above the poverty line and a small deterioration in their living standard
is likely to pull them back below.
5. Several  studies  of  income  poverty6  indicate  that  access  to  physical  infrastructure,
including roads, is one of the most influential factors in reducing poverty. Transport affects the
general welfare of the poor either directly or indirectly depending on the activities involved.
Experience shows that road transport often plays an important role in the income generation
and redistribution process with direct effects, such as providing basic access to education,
health, and markets, and improving access to social and economic opportunities, including labor
and product markets, schools, and clinics. Road transport also contributes to empowerment of
the poor enabling their participation in community and wider decision making, and overcoming
social, cultural, and physical barriers, including geographical isolation. Adequate road transport
makes it possible for constituents to get to meeting places and town centers, facilitates the flow
of information, and so facilitates political and social participation.
6. With  the  rapidly  increasing  transformation  of  Viet  Nam’s  economy  from  a  centrally
planned  to  a  socialist  market  economy  system,  the  Government  continues  to  reorient  its
policies;  reorganize  public  administration;  and  deregulate  industry,  liberalize  prices,  and
commercialize state enterprises in all sectors, including transport. The transition of Viet Nam’s
transport sector requires that transport agencies and operators continue to adapt to the new
economic  environment  to  improve  transport  efficiency  and  to  create  an  institutional,  legal,
financial, and policy framework conducive to sustainable economic growth.
2.  Transport Policy and Institutions
7. At the highest level, the National Assembly makes decisions on major economic policies,
and approves the national plan and state budget, prepared by the Ministry of Planning and

8. At  the  provincial  and  district  level,  planning  and  programming  for  transport  sector
investments and operations are vested with the provincial departments of transport (PDOTs),
which are responsible to their respective provincial people’s committees (PPCs).9 The PDOTs
have no direct responsibility to MOT except for the implementation of some road works on the
national  highways,  but  they  have  links  to  MOT  to  carry  out  certain  works  such  as  those
proposed in the provinces under the Project. While the PDOTs carry out traffic counts, these
counts are not yet fully developed into a structured system. Similarly planning and programming
functions within MOT are not yet fully developed to include modern economic analysis methods
and cost recovery systems in transport sector planning and project selection. Methodology and
systems are slowly being introduced through MOT staff participation in recently completed and
ongoing ADB and WB-funded TA that include transport-related studies, seminars, lectures, and
study tours. Formal training and a clear definition of administrative responsibility and authority
are required for a full appreciation of such techniques and systems.
3.  Road Network and Traffic
9. Viet Nam’s transport system is extensive, comprising about 205,000 km of roads, 2,600
km  of  railways,  19,500  km  of  navigable  waterways,  seven  main  ports,  three  international
airports, and 13 smaller airports serving domestic traffic. The core road network is classified into
national, provincial, district, and urban roads and others (Appendix 3). The road density of 0.36
km/square km compares favorably with that of other developing countries.10 Road transport is
the dominant mode, carrying about 70 percent of freight ton-km and about 80 percent of
passenger-km.  The  demand  for  road  transport  is  increasing  rapidly,  but  traffic  varies
considerably between and within regions. From 1990 to 1997, total transport demand increased
at an average annual rate of 26 percent for passengers and 35 percent for freight. Over the
same period the vehicle fleet increased at an average annual rate of 9 percent (Supplementary
Appendix A), and as of May 2001 reached around 500,000 motor vehicles (cars, pickups,
buses, and trucks). Of the approximately 254,000 trucks of all types in the country, about 30
percent belong to the private sector. Overall vehicle density, remains, however, low except for
the high number of two-wheeled vehicles (7.0 million). The latter vehicles cause problems in
terms of capacity utilization, traffic hazards, and increasing number of accidents particularly in
urban areas; their popularity and use is growing rapidly in rural areas. The recorded road
accidents increased 3.8 times from 1990 to 1999 (para. 48).

10. Although the entire road network is relatively extensive, it is substantially deficient in
quality, mainly because much of the infrastructure in the northern part of the country was
originally constructed 50 to 100 years ago. Even with some recent improvements, maintenance
and rehabilitation are still constrained by a lack of resources. While geometric standards are
generally adequate, pavements were not rehabilitated when needed, the residual strength of
most roads is very poor, and while the riding surface is fair because of continual but costly
pothole patching and resealing, major maintenance, rehabilitation, or improvement is urgently
needed. In all, 57 percent of national roads and about 25 percent of provincial roads are still in
poor  condition.  District  and  commune  roads  are  usually  earth  or  gravel  surfaced,  in  poor
condition, and not passable to motorized traffic, especially during the rainy season, which
makes access to many villages difficult. Some mountainous areas are still inaccessible by road.
Motor vehicles cannot access 606 (6 percent) of the commune centers.
4.  Road Management and Administration
a.  Regulation and Organization
11. While VRA was established in 1993 by decree (interim regulation), the new Road Traffic
Act was passed in June 2001 and is expected to come into force on 1 January 2002. This
clearly defines the roles of MOT and other agencies, including at the provincial level, in the
areas of road planning, construction, maintenance, road transport operations, and road safety.
MOT is responsible for planning the national road and expressway network and the Government
is responsible for its approval. Planning for provincial roads is the responsibility of the PDOTs;
plans are submitted to the PPCs for approval after obtaining MOT recommendations. The
planning of urban roads similarly is carried out by the PPCs and submitted to the Government
for approval after getting recommendations and advice from both MOT and the Ministry of
Construction.  The  planning  of  district  and  lower  roads  is  carried  out  by  agencies  at  that
administrative level and approved by the PPCs. The road construction program for the national
road  network  is  formulated  by  MOT  and  approved  by  the  Government,  while  that  for  the
provincial road network is formulated by the PDOTs and approved by the PPCs after obtaining
the written advice of MOT. MOT is also responsible for stipulating the general norms and
standards for road management and maintenance of public roads, but is directly responsible for
the maintenance program of only the national road network. Responsibility for the maintenance
program of provincial roads is with the PDOTs. The budget for maintenance of provincial roads
is decided by MOF and MPI after consultation with the PDOTs. MOT is also responsible for (i)
implementing road safety engineering, driver training and testing, vehicle inspection, and road
safety research; (ii) determining vehicle load limits, and for driver licenses including regulating
driver instruction and driver testing; and (iii) setting the parameters for the issuance of licenses
for passenger and goods transport, as well as for the management of bus and truck stations,
although the PPCs actually grant licenses to operate transport services and stations.
12. Because the Road Traffic Act does not spell out the role of VRA, a new permanent
decree is needed to define the functions and roles of VRA, which was earlier governed by
temporary decrees. This new decree will replace Decree 07/CP (1993), which established VRA,
and  Decree  167  (1999),  which  decentralized  road  management.  This  is  especially  critical
because the two decrees differ significantly on VRA’s functions. Under Decree 07, VRA is
responsible  for  managing  national  road  infrastructure  and  administering  road  transport
throughout Viet Nam. However, under Decree 167, VRA is directly responsible for managing
only sections of the national roads as entrusted by MOT and the remainder of the national road
sections are assigned to the control of the PPCs. VRA currently directly manages approximately
8,000 km representing about 50 percent of the national road network.

5
13. VRA is led by a chairperson and has about 17,775 staff organized on a decentralized
basis (Appendix 4). It (or its subsidiaries) carries out road maintenance, road toll collection, road
construction, road transport operations, river crossing operations, enforcement of vehicle weight
limits, transport consultancies, education and training, engineering design, project management,
and quarry exploitation. However, VRA has several weaknesses. The TA component of Loan
1487 (footnote 1) found that (i) road network management responsibilities are unclear and
overlapping; (ii) strategic planning and programming for roads is lacking; (iii) performance is
input and output driven instead of being driven by user or outcome needs; and (iv) VRA is
lacking key knowledge and capacity.
14. VRA does not currently fully execute the tasks and functions specified in Decree 07.
Although the decree vests VRA with the responsibility for administering roads throughout Viet
Nam, including road traffic and transport development planning and strategies; VRA information,
databases, and capacity to develop plans, strategies, standards, mechanisms, and policies are
poor and have not been fully executed. VRA does not have a strong role in influencing road
investment  decisions.  The  project  management  units  (PMUs)  manage  projects  funded  by
international  agencies,  as  well  as  implement  road  rehabilitation,  upgrading,  and  new
construction on national roads with little or no VRA involvement. Even in the field of routine
maintenance, VRA is directly responsible for the routine maintenance of only 50 percent of the
national road network. The remainder is carried out by the PDOTs, which are also responsible
for the provincial road network in their respective provinces. The regional road maintenance
units (RRMUs) under VRA carry out routine maintenance either themselves or through their
road repair and management companies based on instructions from VRA or MOT, with the
Government regulating the price.
15. With  the  decentralization  brought  about  by  Decree  167,  no  agency  has  taken
responsibility for strategic planning and programming for roads. Planning is primarily a process
of affiliated units determining local needs with the resulting plan being a consolidation of bottom
up  inputs  without  adequate  analysis  of  priorities  or  standards  against  which  to  evaluate
proposals. Although Decree 07 intends for the whole road network to be managed in a unified
manner, regardless of the distinction between the road networks and their sources of funding,
VRA does not provide either the management or input to budgeting to support this goal. VRA
performance monitoring is also weak. The road condition of only 2,500 km of national highway
has been evaluated. Generally VRA measures its performance in terms of inputs and outputs,
e.g., amount of money spent or number of licenses issued instead of outcomes like road
condition, impact on users, etc. As MOT has limited planning skills, its coverage, and detailed
planning and programming function for roads will be transferred to VRA. VRA is developing a
comprehensive  road  database  and  is  gaining  experience  through  technology  transfer  from
international consultants. However, VRA’s institutional development needs to be intensified to (i)
operationalize VRA as the road infrastructure and road transport planning agency, and (ii)
strengthen and build capacity at VRA in planning and programming for both maintenance and
capital investment activities. This is important because although presently the capital investment
needs and priorities are obvious, they will become less so as implementation of the high priority
projects is progressively completed.
b.  Maintenance
16. MOT through VRA and the RRMUs is responsible for programming the maintenance of
the national road network and provides advice to the PDOTs on maintenance of provincial
roads.  MOT  issues  technical  standards  and  guidelines  for  all  road  classes.  The  road
maintenance companies under the RRMUs are responsible for maintaining major national roads
(46 percent of the national road network), while the PDOTs are responsible for the remainder of

6
the national road network and the provincial, district, and commune roads. While this is not a
very efficient or consistent organization for national road maintenance management, alternative
arrangements  with  VRA  playing  a  key  role  are  being  developed  and  discussed  with  the
Government.
17. A  study  on  developing  a  road  maintenance  strategy11  estimated  that  maintenance
expenditures for national and provincial roads cover between 30 and 50 percent depending on
the source; thus, maintenance on most of these road networks is being neglected. Despite the
budget problem, the PDOTs and RRMUs have mobilized existing resources to maintain vital
sections  of  these  roads.  Substandard  maintenance  has  resulted  in  relatively  high  surface
roughness  levels,  even  soon  after  repairs.  In  addition,  the  planning  and  programming  for
maintenance  does  not  rely  on  systematic  information  on  road  conditions  and  completed
maintenance activities. An appropriate road maintenance management system is needed to
help planners of VRA, RRMUs, and PDOTs decide on major maintenance intervention levels,
timing, and monitoring. The study undertook a detailed evaluation of selected national and
provincial roads, and recommended that a road inventory management system be put in place
and used as a basis for investment and maintenance planning. Operationally, WB is providing
equipment and TA to the RRMUs to implement maintenance and minor road works on a pilot
basis. For rural and provincial road maintenance, past ADB projects have assisted in developing
initiatives to prepare a maintenance plan and budget, and suggest alternative funding sources.
However, much remains to be done, particularly to strengthen road sector institutions.
c.  Construction Industry
18. Prior to the early 1990s, all major road and bridge construction works were carried out
by force account through six construction corporations directly under MOT. Minor works were
undertaken by the RRMUs, either through contract or force account. Since then, the MOT
construction companies started operating on a commercial basis and formed joint ventures with
international contractors for most of the large internationally funded construction works at the
national  level.  These  joint  ventures  seem  to  have  successfully  completed  large  projects,
although  some  concerns  about  effective  implementation  of  agreements  between  the  joint
venture partners have been raised. For domestically financed or internationally funded smaller
works that allowed local contractors, effective competition has been obtained among the state-
owned contractors and private small contractors operating autonomously. Thus, relatively large
participation  of  private  sector  entities12  has  been  observed  under  ADB-  and  WB-financed
components for provincial, district, and commune roads, which are similar to those under the
Project.
19. WB  has  recently  raised  concerns  about  the  award  of  contracts  to  state-owned
enterprises  (SOEs),  and  award  of  civil  work  contracts  to  private  sector  entities  under  the
ongoing Second Rural Transport Project is conditional. A recent ADB mission13 advised the
Government  about  the  constraints  in  awarding  the  works  to  SOEs  and  has  proposed
consideration of award on a case-by-case basis until a policy framework is agreed. To address
the issue of an appropriate policy framework for SOEs active in the transport sector, a small-
scale TA is expected to be approved in December 2001. This TA, which will be implemented

5.  Road Sector Revenues and Expenditures
20. Road revenues are derived from a wide range of road-user charges. These include
items that are (i) purchase related (import duties on new vehicles, and ownership transfer taxes
when vehicles change hands); (ii) ownership related (annual registration fees); and (iii) use
related (import duties on spare parts, tires, and lubricants). In addition, the pump price of fuel
used for road transport includes an import tax (55 percent for gasoline and 20 percent for
diesel). The luxury tax, introduced in January 1996, is set at 15 percent per liter of the after-tax
import price of gasoline and of imported vehicles. In January 1995, the Government introduced
a surcharge on fuel (presently D500 per liter) used in road transport, based on ADB-financed
TA.14 The purpose is to generate funds for the regular repair and maintenance of the country’s
entire transport system. Of the D500 levy on fuel, approximately D200 is notionally allocated to
VRA for recurrent expenses. The annual revenue generated from the fuel levy is D2,200 billion,
but only about D900 billion (or 41 percent) is actually allocated for road maintenance. The actual
maintenance requirements are about D1,800 billion per annum. The total revenue collected
from  road  users,  thus  exceeds  by  a  substantial  margin  the  resources  allocated  by  the
Government to recurrent road maintenance expenditure.
21. Investment in the transport sector has been about one fourth of public investment in
recent years or about 1.8 percent of gross domestic product (GDP).15 Most capital expenditure
is funded by external sources, while recurrent expenditures are met through the local budget. As
another revenue mechanism, VRA usually charges a toll when a road is improved through
resealing  or  overlays,  part  of  which  goes  into  the  VRA  budget  for  maintenance  and
improvement works. Nevertheless, the total funds available to VRA are less than half of what it
needs. VRA has proposed that the Government increase the fuel surcharge from D500 to D900,
with D200 of this going to VRA; this is currently part of the road fund debate. Lately VRA
increased the number of toll stations to collect more revenues, but these had to be reduced
following  strong  complaints  from  road  users.  VRA  estimates  that  these  measures  would
produce enough revenue to meet their budget requirements including payback of commercial
loans presently used to meet budget shortfalls.16 All these proposals were made as part of an
effort by VRA to establish a dedicated road fund or similar, which is being considered by the
Government.

E.  ADB's Sector Strategy
32. ADB’s overarching objective is the reduction of poverty, followed by good governance,
and private sector development. ADB has worked jointly with 22 Government, financing agency,
and  nongovernment  organization  partnership  groups  to  prepare  an  economic  development
strategy for 2010. For the transport sector this strategy emphasizes a vision that espouses the
“smooth movement of people and goods in an economically, socially, and environmentally
sustainable manner.” This general vision is shared by the various stakeholders and specific
actions to achieve the vision have been identified.
33. Core to the successful improvement of transport sector management is the continuing
process of institutional reform, specifically continued development of VRA with capacity building
and institutional strengthening, and improved and secured funding of maintenance. The thrust of
the  reforms  are  directed  at  equalization  of  state-owned,  transport-related  enterprises,  an
appropriate  legal  and  regulatory  framework,  organizational  and  functional  reform  of  the
ministries, including MOT and MPI, and appropriate devolution of responsibility between central
and local governments. Additionally, adequate financing is needed, not only for the development
of the transport system, but more importantly, for the operation and maintenance of these
facilities. These issues are being addressed by ADB and the aid community.
34. ADB’s new country strategy and program for Viet Nam during 2001, will guide future
operations. Based on this, preparation of a new transport sector strategy for the medium-term

F.  Policy Dialogue
35. The introduction of modern policies is dependent on development of the policy-making
institutions. Since the mid-1990s, ADB has been actively engaged in institutional strengthening
efforts to assist MOT and VRA become modern well-managed agencies. This is a continuing
process  and  considerable  progress  has  been  achieved  that  include  (i)  strengthened  legal
framework and regulation with improved governance, (ii) enhanced financing capability to fund
road maintenance, (iii) improved project implementation capability, and (iv) facilitation of private
sector participation. In brief, VRA was established in 1993 and became responsible for planning,
investment, and maintenance of roads in Viet Nam. The next significant step in legislation was
taken when the National Assembly passed the Road Traffic Act in June 2001 to regulate the
road infrastructure and road transport subsector. This act will come into force in January 2002.
Among other things, the act allows for the entry of the private sector in road transport operations

charges a toll when a road is improved by resealing or overlays, part of which goes into the VRA

maintenance has been formulated for discussion within the Government. A few established

3. Road Maintenance and Investment
43. The  road  subsector  is  a  major  economic  and  social  factor  in  Viet  Nam  with  a
replacement value estimated conservatively at D72 trillion or $9,800 million equivalent or 20
percent of GDP in 1999. Hence proper road maintenance is important to preserve the asset
value and investment to date of this resource. Insufficient road maintenance and investment can
be traced to two main problems: inadequate planning and minimal funding.
44. The Government also needs to make a policy decision for sustainable funding for road
maintenance; the present financing model is clearly unsustainable in the long term. In 1999,
total maintenance funds mobilized were $54.8 million. Out of this, $10.4 million (19 percent) was
from the national budget derived from general revenues and fuel levies. An additional $15.0
million  (27  percent)  came  from  toll  revenues.  However,  administrative  expenses  for  toll
collection are relatively high with the 1999 figure being $4.3 million (20 percent of the total
collection). The largest single source of maintenance financing of $25 million (46 percent) is
from short-term borrowing by VRA to offset late disbursement of national budget allocations.
VRA is fully responsible not just for the repayment of the principal amount but also for all
interest payments;  interest payments will not be covered by future allocations from the national
budget. Delays in repayments of loans by VRA under this funding mechanism are contributing

14
to the rapidly increasing debt account. The final maintenance funding mechanism is for planned
periodic maintenance investment projects for roads with high traffic volumes but not included in
the  annual  national  budget.  VRA  through  the  enterprise  function  of  the  regional  road
maintenance centers (RRMCs) can borrow from commercial sources. In 1999, $4.3 million (8
percent  of  total  maintenance  allocation)  was  raised  using  this  mechanism.  Revenues  are
expected from toll fees associated with the maintenance improvements, first to pay off the loans
and later to support general revenue in the national budget. Initial estimates are that this
revenue collection is not adequate to cover loan repayments and hence the VRA debt account
is increasing.
45. While over half (54 percent) of VRA’s maintenance budget is financed using debt, no
real source of funds is available to service this debt. VRA debt due to interest charges will
continue to rise and if not addressed soon could reach unsustainable proportions. Hence the
current financing model for maintenance is clearly unsustainable, aside from the fact that even
the amount raised through all these mechanisms is insufficient for proper maintenance. Thus, it
is imperative that the Government considers other mechanisms for sustainable financing of
maintenance  activities,  such  as  a  road  fund.  When  considering  sustainable  financing
mechanisms, the sources of revenue, expenditure, and financial control systems need to be
considered to obtain maximum value from the funds. To protect current investment in roads by
ensuring  their  adequate  maintenance,  the  Government  is  considering  how  to  establish  a
dedicated and adequately financed road fund. MOT has agreed, as part of the action plan under
the Project, to a detailed study on potential revenue sources and to develop a mechanism for
sustainable funding of road maintenance, including introduction of a road fund.
46. The Government should also assess how the maintenance activities should be carried
out. At present VRA assigns all routine operation and maintenance work to specific RRMUs and
regional road maintenance centers based on geographic location. Because this does not entail
any competition between maintenance units, VRA cannot determine if maximum benefit is
obtained  from  the  funds  spent.  Allocations  for  periodic  and  unexpected  maintenance  are
allocated on a project basis with only minimal competition between maintenance units. This too
gives rise to issues of ineffectiveness. ADB will continue to dialogue with MOT aiming at
developing  a  truly  competitive  system  for  contracting  out  maintenance  work  so  that  cost-
effectiveness is maximized.

47. Road user charges are a significant source of revenue for the Government in general,
although the charges are low. A 1999 WB study27 found that owners of four-wheel motor

vehicle and the damage it causes to the roads need to be introduced. These matters were

needs assistance to rationalize a modern, efficiency-based road user charge regime in Viet

5.  Road Safety
48. In the past decade, the road accident situation in Viet Nam has worsened considerably
with  the  growth  in  motorization.  In  10  years  from  1990  to  1999,  140,278  accidents  were
recorded  with  45,196  people  killed  and  153,474  injured.  In  1999,  21,220  accidents  were
recorded with over 6,000 fatalities and 25,000 injured persons. Comparison of the accident data
of 1990 and 1999 shows that the number of accidents increased 3.8 times, fatalities 3.2 times,
and injuries 5.2 times. The proposed Project’s technical designs will take road safety into
account, by providing hard shoulders for separation of bicycle and other nonmotorized traffic,
and making safe provision for pedestrian movement within populated areas. The major causes
of accidents are the undisciplined behavior of vehicle operators, bicyclists, and pedestrians; the
confusing and dangerous mix of fast- and slow-moving vehicles; and the use of the pavement
for various nontraffic related purposes. High accident rates are also attributed to inadequate
laws and regulations for vehicles and traffic, their lax enforcement, the poor condition of roads,
and absence of action to identify and improve hazardous locations.
49. To address this growing problem, the Government has set up the National Traffic Safety
Council chaired by a vice minister of MOT and consisting of representatives from all relevant

IV.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT
A.  Rationale
54. Efficient  road  transport,  and  improved  access  in  particular,  is  essential  for  poverty
reduction and economic development. Past efforts in the road subsector have mainly been
directed at upgrading the national highway system, while also improving basic access to the
rural population by improving the lower level district and commune roads. One missing part in
the network development strategy has been improvement of provincial roads, which provide
access to the provincial capitals, to the national highway network, and to the rural population
through  the  district  and  commune  roads.  Improvement  of  the  provincial  roads  will  ensure
effective transport and communication between the rural population connected by commune
and provincial roads with market and distribution centers and the national highway network.
Another priority is continued reform and institutional strengthening of VRA to become a modern
and  efficient  road  administration  agency.  The  adopted  sector  loan  modality  will  support
sustainable  development  of  provincial  roads  and  allow  flexibility  in  selecting  prescreened
subprojects forming part of the PRSDP.

transport efficiency. The Project’s objectives are to (i) improve the provincial road network on
both social and economic grounds; (ii) provide improved access for poor and disadvantaged
groups living in rural communities; (iii) strengthen asset management capacity and maintenance
programs of VRA and the PDOTs; (iv) continue institutional strengthening of VRA and improve
governance in the road subsector; (v) strengthen PDOT capacity to prepare, implement, and

3.  Project Area and Components

Uplands (northeast and northwest), Red River Delta, and North Central Coast. Of the 18 project
provinces, 15 are located in the Northern Mountains and Uplands, two in the Red River Delta,
and one in the North Central Coast. The Northern Mountains and Uplands and the North Central

a.  Provincial Roads Component

higher with traffic ranging from 10 to 400 conventional motor vehicles per day. All roads have a
strong social focus as they serve areas inhabited mainly by the rural poor who could benefit

90. In general, the Project seeks to avoid displacement of any people. In most cases, people
whose houses need to be moved will be able to move just behind the right-of-way, thereby
minimizing the impact. In exceptional cases where displacement cannot be avoided, particular
care will be given in the compensation, resettlement, and rehabilitation of displaced people that
are ethnic minorities. Extensive social preparation and mobilization for ethnic minority groups
will take place prior to any physical resettlement.
91. The Project will not have any negative impact on specific ethnic minority groups located
in the project areas. The selection criteria for the subprojects are designed to ensure that they
do not adversely impact ethnic minorities. The Project will identify ways and measures in which
the benefits from road improvement can be enhanced and where investment can be made in
tandem with other initiatives that cater specifically to the socioeconomic development of ethnic
minority  groups.  This  will  be  done  by  means  of  participatory  detailed  design  of  minority
development plans (EMDPs) under the guidance of the consultants. Such efforts will include (i)
small-scale community infrastructure aimed at improving access of the poor and excluded, such
as  trails,  footbridges,  and  markets;  (ii)  participatory  agricultural  extension  to  increase
productivity;  and  (iii)  support  for  credit  utilization.  Gender  concerns  of  relevance  to  ethnic
minorities will also be addressed by the Project actively facilitating the processes whereby
women are involved in identifying, designing, implementing, monitoring, and evaluating the
EMDPs.
92. The resettlement framework (Appendix 13) was prepared under TA 3455 (footnote 3)
and includes a component for ethnic minority development, which will be applicable in cases
where there are ethnic minority people living within the zone of influence of a subproject road.
The Government has approved the framework. In accordance with the framework, the sample
RP for one core road (Appendix 14) makes provision for an EMDP for communities within the
ZOI of that road. Prior to loan effectiveness, an EMDP component will be prepared and included
in the RPs for the other core roads where there are ethnic minority people living  within the ZOI
of those roads. The PDOTs will be required to prepare and submit RPs to ADB for approval:
the EMDP component must be included for each subproject as required and in accordance with

26
the  criteria  stipulated  in  the  framework.  The  EMDP  component  will  be  prepared  and
implemented following ADB's indigenous people policy.
c. Health Measures
93. Transport  corridors  can  have  significant  impacts  on  the  transmission  of  sexually
transmitted diseases and HIV/AIDS.37 Truck drivers operating along the roads and commercial
sex workers are identified as two of the major high-risk groups. As the Project will provide
improved transport links within the country, the risk of STD transmission may increase. Most
labor will be from local areas and will return home at night thus eliminating or minimizing the
need for campsites that would encourage sex workers to establish and operate in those areas.
Most of the roads are short and traversed in a short time. Their improvement is not likely to lead
to the establishment of increased sex trade.
V.  PROJECT JUSTIFICATION
A.  Economic Analysis
94. The methodology for economic analysis presented in Appendix 15 used the traditional
evaluation method where existing and future vehicle operating cost savings are determined and
analyzed to determine if the recommended improvement is warranted in accordance with ADB’s
Guidelines for the Economic Evaluation of Projects. The highway design and maintenance
model was adjusted to the country’s conditions and used to calculate vehicle operating costs
and savings. The main inputs to this are vehicle operating, construction, and maintenance
costs, along with resettlement, supervision, and physical contingency costs. As the roads are in
18 very poor provinces of northern Viet Nam, they were evaluated and ranked in social and area
economic terms. This ranking helps to set priorities and ensure that roads serving the poorest
areas will be candidates for improvement.
95. The provinces have a combined total of 8,100 km of provincial roads. These were
initially screened to eliminate roads that were recently improved; are scheduled for improvement
or in good condition, or have very low priority in terms of low traffic volume. This reduced the
length to 2,800 km. Based on a socioeconomic ranking, these roads were then reduced to 1,600
km that have high priority in socioeconomic terms; these form the basis of the Project. To
prepare the project roads, an initial set of core roads was selected to represent different parts of
the  project  area  reflecting  differences  in  topography,  geology,  and  social  and  other
characteristics. The core roads were subject to a complete economic evaluation using detailed
design, and vehicle operating costs, all adjusted according to appropriate shadow prices and
conversion factors. Traffic growth rates were derived from the relationship between GDP and
the elasticity of transport demand for motorcycles, passenger transport, and cargo. These were
then adjusted to reflect project area characteristics. This yielded annual growth rates ranging
from 5 to 13 percent up to 2005, and then declining to 4 to 5 percent thereafter.
96. The project roads are generally lightly traveled with motorcycles comprising about 80
percent of the traffic on many roads. The level of improvement will mainly be to class V roads,
and incorporates a formation width of 6.5 m and a sealed carriageway of 3.5 m. Analysis of the
maintenance costs between gravel and sealed surface shows that sealed roads provide a better
riding surface longer and given the effects of heavy rainfall common to the project area, the cost
of maintaining sealed roads is less than that of gravel-surfaced roads.

B.  Social Dimensions
98. The  social  dimensions  of  the  Project  (resettlement,  ethnic  minority  development,
stakeholder  participation,  and  construction  and  maintenance  labor  opportunities)  are  all
designed to facilitate more equitable and sustainable distribution of benefits, particularly for the
poorest and socially excluded in the project area. The summary social and poverty impact
assessment of the Project is presented in Supplementary Appendix D.
99. Direct harm may result from project development, as well as indirect adverse social
impacts, including (i) individual and community loss of agricultural land or land associated with
commercial  activities  due  to  land  clearance  and  acquisition  issues,  (ii)  potential  for  ethnic
minority groups not being able to participate in or benefit from the Project to the same extent as
the kinh or to suffer disproportionately from adverse cultural effects, and (iii) accidents due to
lack of road and traffic safety both during and after construction. These potentially adverse
impacts will be mitigated by the Project through measures including (i) community participation
and effective planning and implementation of RPs and EMDPs, and (ii) effective construction
supervision and enforcement of contract specifications, as well as implementation of safety
features.
100. In addition, the mechanism for promoting participation will have the objective of binding
together the social dimensions of the Project with the technical, environmental, and economic

28
features to make this an integrated development project aimed at maximizing development
impact and poverty reduction.
1.  Potential for Community Participation in the Project
101. Project  preparation  has  taken  a  participatory  approach  that  combined  workshops,
individual meetings, key informant interviews, and a field survey of 21 roads, to engender
community awareness of the Project and to ascertain the degree to which people may benefit or
be affected by various subprojects. This participatory approach will continue during preparation,
implementation, and monitoring of RPs and EMDPs.
102. Implementation of the subprojects provides opportunities to include local involvement in
the construction and maintenance of the provincial roads. While there could be some reluctance
to  utilize  local  labor  as  a  component  of  construction,  many  benefits  can  be  derived  from
encouraging community participation in road development. Firstly, it can engender a high level
of acceptance and ownership of the subproject. Secondly, it reduces the likelihood of opposition
to the subproject and the potential for delays. Thirdly, and perhaps more importantly, it ensures
that the needs of the end-users and potential beneficiaries are adequately incorporated into
subproject design; this is particularly important for road projects that are being used as engines
for poverty reduction.
103. The success of any community participation component within the Project will rest upon
the  establishment  of  appropriate  communication  networks  and  protocols,  for  which
organizations such as the Women's Union will provide at least the initial mechanism.
104. Sufficient and adequate social preparation and mobilization is also paramount if using
local labor is to be successful within the Project and is to contribute to poverty reduction in any
substantial way. This would require some months of awareness building by social mobilizers
and training in participation in a formal and regular wage-earning system, which is likely to be a
foreign concept to residents of remote and disadvantaged communities, and particularly ethnic
minority  communities  that  have  difficulty  participating  in  the  market/wage  economy  due  to
language and communication skills.
105. Communities can also participate in identification of needs of minority communities and
development; implementation, and monitoring of EMDPs; as well as resettlement planning,
implementation, and monitoring of RPs.
106. Using this type of participatory approach will enhance the poverty reduction potential of
the Project. In conjunction with attaining the Project's overriding objectives of rural poverty
reduction and improvement of access, it will provide ample opportunity to process subprojects
that  are  a  part  of  an  integrated  program  of  community-based  and  sustainable  commune
development.
C.  Impact on Poverty
107. The conclusions of the social and poverty assessment are that the Project will create
significant positive impacts for the communities within the ZOI of each subproject. While some
marginal adverse effects could be experienced, predominantly through land clearance and
acquisition and impacts on ethnic minorities, the effects of these can be adequately mitigated
provided the affected communities are given the opportunity for meaningful participation and
consultation, for which processes have been established.

29
108. Social and poverty reduction benefits can be realized from subprojects implementation
by providing improved access to basic health and education facilities and other social services
in the provincial and district centers and also at the commune level in cases where provincial
roads are the primary access. Improving the access to and between communes will also help
reduce the remoteness and isolation of ethnic minority groups, a factor that is considered to be
one of the main causes of their severe poverty. Poverty reduction aspects of the Project could
be enhanced by engaging affected communities and providing first priority to the poor and
disadvantaged in the actual construction of subprojects. The modality for doing this is being
developed.
109. The Project will thus achieve its overriding objectives of poverty reduction, improving the
reliability of access to social and economic opportunities, and reducing the cost associated with
transportation on the provincial road network, providing the potential for increasing agricultural
output,  and  improving  the  quality  of  life  and  social  and  economic  well-being  of  the  poor,
disadvantaged, and ethnic minority sectors of the population.
110. The Project has the potential to accrue a range of benefits to poor and disadvantaged
communities alike, and if some subprojects can be pursued in tandem with specific poverty
reduction, rural development, or ethnic minority development programs, the benefits of the
Project can be enhanced. In general the types of benefits that can be expected to follow from
subproject implementation include
(i)  providing essential transport infrastructure and services and thereby increasing
economic growth, as well as access to those services necessary for the social
development  of  the  population  increases  the  productive  value  of  limited
resources of the poor, creates employment opportunities, and provides better
access to essential services and markets;
(ii)  providing for the special needs of the poor that are created through efforts to
increase development improves the quality of life of the poor, provides affordable
travel, and increases employment opportunities and opportunities for the poor to
move into the economic and agricultural mainstream;
(iii)  sustaining essential transport infrastructure and services for the poor increases
employment opportunities for the poor, disadvantaged, and vulnerable groups;
and equips these groups with new skills and provides additional opportunities for
complementary poverty reduction initiatives; and
(iv)  enhancing the mobility of women increases their participation in the labor force,
increases the economic productivity of women, and improves women's access to
resources and essential services.
111. The Project is also in an excellent position to encourage investment in areas that support
rural development and poverty reduction; in some cases the subprojects could be advanced as
part of a multisectoral rural development project. The TA (footnote 3) identified the types of
integrated programs and complementary activities that could be targeted for investment. If they
cannot  be  included  within  the  Project,  these  activities  will  be  investigated  during  project
implementation for potential inclusion under a grant through aid coordination.

30
D.  Risks
112. The major risks associated with this Project relate to VRA’s progress with institutional
reform, the quality of works, adherence to time schedules, timeliness of Government approvals
for subprojects and construction contracts, availability of sufficient qualified resettlement and
social development specialists to ensure adequate and timely preparation and implementation
of the RPs and EMDPs, and the timely realization of benefits that would accrue to the rural poor
and especially to the ethnic minority population. The Government has adopted an action plan for
institutional reform of VRA and its implementation.
113. For projects of this type the Government has delegated the authority to award contracts
to the PDOTs with approvals required only by PMU-5 and MOT. This should help speed up the
approval process. Most of the PDOTs have some experience either with ADB, DFID, JICA, or
WB financed projects. This will help to ensure timely implementation and understanding of the
ADB procedures. Nevertheless, since PMU-5 has not been involved with ADB-funded projects,
PMU-5 staff will need to become proficient with ADB requirements. Some PMU-5 staff have
been trained at ADB headquarters in Manila and more training is planned. Consulting services
for  subproject  preparation  and  implementation  are  provided  under  the  Project  and  will  be
charged with training the PMU-5 and PDOT staff.
114. People will require time to adjust to a significant improvement of the intermediate goods
that affect their lives, such as improved access to opportunities not previously recognized or
considered  available.  To  help  achieve  maximum  benefit,  particularly  to  the  ethnic  minority
peoples populating much of the hilly and mountainous areas of the project area, the EMDPs
have been prepared for the core roads and will be prepared for future subprojects.
VI.  ASSURANCES
A.  Specific Assurances
115. The  Government  has  given  the  following  assurances,  in  addition  to  the  standard
assurances, which have been incorporated in the legal documents:
(i)  Implementation. The Government will ensure that road construction is carried out
following good environmental practices including appropriate selection of quarry
and borrow sites and their subsequent rehabilitation after use;  proper disposal of
construction  wastes  and  materials;  use  of  good  environmental  design  and
construction techniques that ensure slope stability and drainage; minimization of
construction  impacts  such  as  dust,  diversion  of  stream  flow  and  increased
turbulence, equipment noise, etc.; and other environmental impacts associated
with road construction and maintenance.
(ii)  When project roads pass through or near protected or sensitive areas (nature
reserves parks, conservation areas, biodiversity reserves, cultural and historical
sites, etc.), the Government will ensure cooperation between the PDOT and the
area  authority  responsible  for  preparing  and  implementing  the  protective
measure.  This  may  include  any  combination  of  area  demarcation,  fencing,
checkpoints, speed bumps, wildlife passage zones, patrols, or other measures to
preserve  the  integrity  of  the  area  from  encroachment  or  environmental
degradation due to road improvement and increased access.

31
(iii)  Midway  through  project  implementation  (end  2003),  the  Government,  in
cooperation with ADB, will undertake a detailed review of the Project and its
implementation status. The scope of the review will include all aspects of the
Project, including land acquisition and resettlement. Following completion of the
review, the Borrower or Government will take all necessary actions to correct any
problems identified in project implementation.
(iv)  Resettlement. The Government will take all measures necessary to implement to
the satisfaction of ADB the RPs developed for project roads, including the EMDP
components of each RP. The Government will ensure that all people affected by
the Project are compensated and resettled in accordance with the requirements
of the resettlement framework, and RPs, the Government's procedures, and
ADB's involuntary resettlement policy.
(v)  Ethnic Minorities. The Government will ensure that the EMDPs are designed and
implemented  in  accordance  with  the  resettlement  framework,  the  RPs,  and
ADB's indigenous people policy and in coordination with the Government’s ethnic
minority program.
(vi)  Health Risks. The Government will ensure that any civil works contracts for
works to be carried out under this Project require the civil works contractors to
conduct information and education campaigns on sexually transmitted diseases
and HIV/AIDS for construction workers as part of a health and safety program at
campsites during the construction period.
(vii)  Labor Laws. The Government will set employment targets for women for road
construction activities, as well as require contractors not to differentiate wages
between men and women for work of equal type. Also, child labor will not be
allowed in the construction activities and camps.
(viii)  Operation  and  Maintenance.  The  Government  will  ensure  that  the  improved
roads  are  maintained  to  design  standards  and  in  accordance  with  sound
maintenance  practices.  The  Government  will  ensure  that  annual  road
maintenance plans are prepared for the improved roads, on the basis of the
agreed-upon maintenance standards, traffic volumes, and assessment of needs.
(ix)  Road  Sector  Reform.  The  Government  will  continue  strengthening  the  legal
framework, regulation, and institutions active in the road subsector, specifically
VRA, in accordance with the action plan agreed to by ADB. New regulations for
VRA’s mandate, responsibilities, and functions improving upon the framework for
interim regulation of VRA, will be enacted by 31 December 2002.
(x)  Sector Studies. The Government will keep ADB informed of all transport sector
and road subsector studies undertaken in Viet Nam; provide ADB with copies of
all available documents relevant to such studies, including consultants' reports;
and  ensure that ADB has the opportunity to comment on the recommendations
contained therein.
(xi)  The Government and ADB will from time to time exchange views on progress in
carrying  out  the  policies  and  actions  recommended  by  transport  and  road
studies. The Government will maintain a policy dialogue with ADB on problems

32
and constraints affecting the growth and development of the road subsector, and
in particular on road maintenance and investment, and road user charges.
(xii)  Selection of Subprojects. A subproject is eligible for financing under the loan if it:
(a)  is  economically,  technically,  and  environmentally  feasible  and  has  an
economic internal rate of return greater than 12 percent;
(b)  has received all applicable Governmental clearances; and
(c)  complies with ADB’s and the Government’s procedural requirements, and
resettlement, social, and environment policies and guidelines.
(xiii)  Project  Performance  Monitoring.  The  Government  will  carry  out  project
performance monitoring and evaluation by compiling and analyzing appropriate
traffic and socioeconomic data and other data for project roads. Prior to the
commencing  of  civil  works,  PMU-5  and  ADB  will  agree  on  the  data  to  be
collected and the methodology for their analysis based upon the baseline survey,
which was carried out in 2001.
B.  Conditions for Loan Effectiveness
116. The Government will have approved RP for each core road, as required, and will have
provided the necessary funding and staffing at PMU-5 and the PDOTs.
C.  Conditions for Award of Contract for Civil Works
117. ADB will not approve award of any civil works contract for any road to be financed from
the loan proceeds unless the Government has completed satisfactorily and in accordance with
the approved RP for that road compensation payment  and relocation to new sites, and ensured
rehabilitation assistance is in place prior to obtaining possession and rights to the required land.
VII.  RECOMMENDATION
118. I am satisfied that the proposed loan would comply with the Articles of Agreement of
ADB and recommend that the Board approve the loan in various currencies equivalent to
Special Drawing Rights 55,327,000 to the Socialist Republic of Viet Nam for the Provincial
Roads Improvement Sector Project, with a term of 32 years, including a grace period of 8 years,
and with an interest charge at the rate of 1 percent per annum during the grace period and 1.5
percent per annum thereafter, and such other terms and conditions as are substantially in
accordance with those set forth in the draft Loan Agreement presented to the Board.

A. Introduction
1. The Project is based on the need to fill the gap left by the improvement of national roads
and district and commune roads in the project area. Improvement of the provincial road network
will help bring the provincial facilities and related economic opportunities closer to the rural poor
population. The total length of the provincial road network in the 18 provinces in the project area
is  about  8,100  kilometers  (km)  serving  a  total  population  of  about  19  million.  Poverty
characterizes the project area especially in the rural areas with poverty incidence generally
increasing  with  distance  from  the  economic  centers  of  Hanoi  and  Haiphong.  Given  the
resources and population density, economic and social development has significant potential.
The Project thus identifies the provincial road network and based on a sample of these roads
identifies and prioritizes about 2,800 km justified for improvement on both economic and social
grounds. These 2,800 km were further screened to yield about 1,600 km considered to have the
highest development and economic priority. Nine core roads have been fully prepared for
implementation following loan effectiveness.

2. The part of the Project subject to this economic evaluation is the proposed improvement

1,600 km, although the total length to be improved will depend on the actual cost of the

comprise upgrading to a class V road characterized by a 6.5 meters (m) formation width and a
